If the Administrator subsequently returns property of a similar kind under section 610 of this title, the value of the property may be deducted from the Fund.

subsection.heading: Use of Acquisition Services Fund To Cover Costs.—
subsection.content: The Acquisition Services Fund provided for in section 321 of this title is available for use by or under the direction and control of the Administrator of General Services to pay the costs of carrying out section 602 of this title, including the cost of purchasing or renting motor vehicles and related equipment and supplies.

paragraph.heading: In general.—
paragraph.content: The Administrator shall set prices for furnishing motor vehicles and related services under section 602 of this title. Prices shall be set to recover, so far as practicable, all costs of carrying out section 602 of this title.

paragraph.heading: Increment for replacement cost.—
paragraph.content: In the Administrator’s discretion, prices may include an increment for the estimated replacement cost of motor vehicles and related equipment and supplies. Notwithstanding section 321(f) of this title, the increment may be retained as a part of the capital of the Acquisition Services Fund but is available only to replace motor vehicles and related equipment and supplies.

subsection.heading: Accounting Method.—
subsection.content: The purchase price of motor vehicles and related equipment, and any increment for estimated replacement cost, shall be recovered only through charges for the cost of amortization. Costs shall be determined, and financial reports prepared, in accordance with the accrual accounting method.

subsection.heading: In General.—
subsection.content: The Director of the Office of Personnel Management shall prescribe regulations to govern executive agencies in authorizing civilian personnel to operate Federal Government-owned motor vehicles for official purposes within the States of the United States, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, and the territories and possessions of the United States.

subsection.heading: Elements of the Regulations.—
subsection.content: The regulations shall prescribe standards of physical fitness for authorized operators. The regulations may require operators and prospective operators to obtain state and local licenses or permits that are required to operate similar vehicles for other than official purposes.

subsection.heading: Agency Orders.—
subsection.chapeau: The head of each executive agency shall issue orders and directives necessary for compliance with the regulations. The orders and directives shall provide for—

paragraph.content: periodically testing the physical fitness of operators and prospective operators; and
suspension and revocation of authority to operate.

content.p: The Administrator of General Services shall maintain an accurate record of the cost of establishing, maintaining, and operating each motor vehicle pool or system established under section 602 of this title.

The Administrator of General Services, in the operation of motor vehicle pools or systems under this subchapter, may provide for the sale and use of scrip, tokens, tickets, and similar devices to collect payment.

subsection.heading: In General.—
subsection.chapeau: Under regulations prescribed by the Administrator of General Services, every motor vehicle acquired and used for official purposes within the United States, or the territories or possessions of the United States, by any federal agency or by the District of Columbia shall be conspicuously identified by showing, on the vehicle—

subparagraph.content: the full name of the department, establishment, corporation, or agency that uses the vehicle and the service for which the vehicle is used; or
a title that readily identifies the department, establishment, corporation, or agency that uses the vehicle and that is descriptive of the service for which the vehicle is used; and

paragraph.content: the legend “For official use only”.

subsection.heading: Exceptions.—
subsection.content: The regulations prescribed pursuant to this section may provide for exemptions when conspicuous identification would interfere with the purpose for which a vehicle is acquired and used.

section.heading: Discontinuance of motor vehicle pool or system

subsection.heading: In General.—
subsection.content: The Administrator of General Services shall discontinue a motor vehicle pool or system if there are no actual savings realized (based on accounting as provided in section 605 of this title) during a reasonable period of not longer than two successive fiscal years.

subsection.heading: Return of Comparable Property.—
subsection.content: If a motor vehicle pool or system is discontinued, the Administrator shall return to each agency involved motor vehicles and related equipment and supplies similar in kind and reasonably comparable in value to any motor vehicles and related equipment and supplies which were previously taken over by the Administrator.

content.p: During the regular course of the duties of the Administrator of General Services, if the Administrator becomes aware of a violation of section 1343, 1344, or 1349(b) of title 31 or of section 641 of title 18 involving the conversion by a Federal Government official or employee of a Government-owned or leased motor vehicle to the official or employee’s own use or to the use of others, the Administrator shall report the violation to the head of the agency in which the official or employee is employed, for further investigation and either appropriate disciplinary action under section 1343, 1344, or 1349(b) of title 31 or, if appropriate, referral to the Attorney General for prosecution under section 641 of title 18.

paragraph.heading: Administrator.—
paragraph.content: The term “Administrator” means the Administrator of General Services.

paragraph.heading: Council.—
paragraph.content: The term “Council” means the Federal Real Property Council established by section 623(a).

paragraph.heading: Director.—
paragraph.content: The term “Director” means the Director of the Office of Management and Budget.

paragraph.heading: Federal agency.—
paragraph.chapeau: The term “Federal agency” means—

subparagraph.content: an executive department or independent establishment in the executive branch of the Government; or
a wholly owned Government corporation (other than the United States Postal Service).

paragraph.heading: Field office.—
paragraph.content: The term “field office” means any office of a Federal agency that is not the headquarters office location for the Federal agency.

paragraph.heading: Postal property.—
paragraph.content: The term “postal property” means any property owned or leased by the United States Postal Service.

paragraph.heading: Public-private partnership.—
paragraph.content: The term “public-private partnership” means any partnership or working relationship between a Federal agency and a corporation, individual, or nonprofit organization for the purpose of financing, constructing, operating, managing, or maintaining one or more Federal real property assets.

paragraph.heading: Underutilized property.—
paragraph.chapeau: The term “underutilized property” means a portion or the entirety of any real property, including any improvements, that is used—

subparagraph.content: irregularly or intermittently by the accountable Federal agency for program purposes of the Federal agency; or
for program purposes that can be satisfied only with a portion of the property.

section.heading: Collocation among United States Postal Service properties

subsection.heading: Identification of Postal Property.—
subsection.chapeau: Each year, the Postmaster General shall—

paragraph.content: identify a list of postal properties with space available for use by Federal agencies; and

paragraph.chapeau: not later than September 30, submit the list to—

subparagraph.content: the Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs of the Senate; and
the Committee on Oversight and Government Reform of the House of Representatives.

subsection.heading: Voluntary Identification of Postal Property.—
subsection.content: Each year, the Postmaster General may submit the list under subsection (a) to the Council.

heading.inline: Submission of List of Postal Properties to Federal Agencies.—

paragraph.heading: In general.—
paragraph.content: Not later than 30 days after the completion of a list under subsection (a), the Council shall provide the list to each Federal agency.

paragraph.heading: Review by federal agencies.—
paragraph.chapeau: Not later than 90 days after the receipt of the list submitted under paragraph (1), each Federal agency shall—

subparagraph.content: review the list;
review properties under the control of the Federal agency; and
recommend collocations if appropriate.

subsection.heading: Terms of Collocation.—
subsection.content: On approval of the recommendations under subsection (c) by the Postmaster General and the applicable agency head, the Federal agency or appropriate landholding entity may work with the Postmaster General to establish appropriate terms of a lease for each postal property.

subsection.heading: Rule of Construction.—
subsection.content: Nothing in this section exceeds, modifies, or supplants any other Federal law relating to any competitive bidding process governing the leasing of postal property.

section.heading: Establishment of a Federal Real Property Council

subsection.heading: Establishment.—
subsection.content: There is established a Federal Real Property Council.

subsection.heading: Purpose.—
subsection.chapeau: The purpose of the Council shall be—

paragraph.content: to develop guidance and ensure implementation of an efficient and effective real property management strategy;
to identify opportunities for the Federal Government to better manage property and assets of the Federal Government; and
to reduce the costs of managing property of the Federal Government, including operations, maintenance, and security associated with Federal property.

paragraph.heading: In general.—
paragraph.chapeau: The Council shall be composed exclusively of—

subparagraph.content: the senior real property officers of each Federal agency;
the Deputy Director for Management of the Office of Management and Budget;
the Controller of the Office of Management and Budget;
the Administrator; and
any other full-time or permanent part-time Federal officials or employees, as the Chairperson determines to be necessary.

paragraph.heading: Chairperson.—
paragraph.content: The Deputy Director for Management of the Office of Management and Budget shall serve as Chairperson of the Council.

subparagraph.heading: In general.—
subparagraph.content: The Chairperson shall designate an Executive Director to assist in carrying out the duties of the Council.

subparagraph.heading: Qualifications.—
subparagraph.chapeau: The Executive Director shall—

clause.content: be appointed from among individuals who have substantial experience in the areas of commercial real estate and development, real property management, and Federal operations and management; and
hold no outside employment that may conflict with duties inherent to the position.

paragraph.heading: In general.—
paragraph.content: The Council shall meet subject to the call of the Chairperson.

paragraph.heading: Minimum.—
paragraph.content: The Council shall meet not fewer than 4 times each year.

subsection.heading: Duties.—
subsection.chapeau: The Council, in consultation with the Director and the Administrator, shall—

paragraph.chapeau: not later than 1 year after the date of enactment of this subchapter, establish a real property management plan template, to be updated annually, which shall include performance measures, specific milestones, measurable savings, strategies, and Government-wide goals based on the goals established under section 524(a)(7) to reduce surplus property or to achieve better utilization of underutilized property, and evaluation criteria to determine the effectiveness of real property management that are designed—

subparagraph.content: to enable Congress and heads of Federal agencies to track progress in the achievement of property management objectives on a Government-wide basis;
to improve the management of real property; and
to allow for comparison of the performance of Federal agencies against industry and other public sector agencies;

paragraph.content: develop utilization rates consistent throughout each category of space, considering the diverse nature of the Federal portfolio and consistent with nongovernmental space use rates;
develop a strategy to reduce the reliance of Federal agencies on leased space for long-term needs if ownership would be less costly;
provide guidance on eliminating inefficiencies in the Federal leasing process;
compile a list of field offices that are suitable for collocation with other property assets;
research best practices regarding the use of public-private partnerships to manage properties and develop guidelines for the use of those partnerships in the management of Federal property; and

paragraph.chapeau: not later than 1 year after the date of enactment of this subchapter and annually during the 4-year period beginning on the date that is 1 year after the date of enactment of this subchapter and ending on the date that is 5 years after the date of enactment of this subchapter, the Council shall submit to the Director a report that contains—

subparagraph.content: a list of the remaining excess property that is real property, surplus property that is real property, and underutilized property of each Federal agency;
the progress of the Council toward developing guidance for Federal agencies to ensure that the assessment required under section 524(a)(11)(B) is carried out in a uniform manner;
the progress of Federal agencies toward achieving the goals established under section 524(a)(7);
if necessary, recommendations for legislation or statutory reforms that would further the goals of the Council, including streamlining the disposal of excess or underutilized real property; and
a list of entities that are consulted under subsection (f).

subsection.heading: Consultation.—
subsection.chapeau: In carrying out the duties described in subsection (e), the Council shall also consult with representatives of—

paragraph.content: State, local, and tribal authorities, as appropriate, and other affected communities; and

paragraph.chapeau: appropriate private sector entities and nongovernmental organizations that have expertise in areas of—

subparagraph.content: commercial real estate and development;
government management and operations;
space planning;
community development, including transportation and planning;
historic preservation; and
providing housing to the homeless population.

subsection.heading: Council Resources.—
subsection.content: The Director and the Administrator shall provide staffing, and administrative support for the Council, as appropriate.

subsection.heading: Access to Report.—
subsection.chapeau: The Council shall provide, on an annual basis, the real property management plan template required under subsection (e)(1) and the reports required under subsection (e)(7) to—

paragraph.content: the Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs of the Senate;
the Committee on Environment and Public Works of the Senate;
the Committee on Oversight and Government Reform of the House of Representatives;
the Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure of the House of Representatives; and
the Comptroller General of the United States.

subsection.heading: Exclusions.—
subsection.chapeau: In this section, surplus property shall not include—

paragraph.content: any military installation (as defined in section 2910 of the Defense Base Closure and Realignment Act of 1990 (10 U.S.C. 2687 note; Public Law 101–510));
any property that is excepted from the definition of the term “property” under section 102;
Indian and native Eskimo property held in trust by the Federal Government as described in section 3301(a)(5)(C)(iii);
real property operated and maintained by the Tennessee Valley Authority pursuant to the Tennessee Valley Authority Act of 1933 (16 U.S.C. 831 et seq.);
any real property the Director excludes for reasons of national security;

paragraph.chapeau: any public lands (as defined in section 203 of the Public Lands Corps Act of 1993 (16 U.S.C. 1722)) administered by—

subparagraph.chapeau: the Secretary of the Interior, acting through—

clause.content: the Director of the Bureau of Land Management;
the Director of the National Park Service;
the Commissioner of Reclamation; or
the Director of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service; or

subparagraph.content: the Secretary of Agriculture, acting through the Chief of the Forest Service; or

paragraph.content: any property operated and maintained by the United States Postal Service.

subsection.heading: In General.—
subsection.chapeau: Except as provided in subsection (b), not later than December 31 of each year following the date of enactment of this subchapter, a Federal agency with independent leasing authority shall submit to the Council a list of all leases, including operating leases, in effect on the date of enactment of this subchapter that includes—

paragraph.content: the date on which each lease was executed;
the date on which each lease will expire;
a description of the size of the space;
the location of the property;
the tenant agency;
the total annual rental payment; and
the amount of the net present value of the total estimated legal obligations of the Federal Government over the life of the contract.

subsection.heading: Exception.—
subsection.chapeau: Subsection (a) shall not apply to—

paragraph.content: the United States Postal Service; or
any other property the Director excludes from subsection (a) for reasons of national security.
